intro: Chamaespartium delphinense, commonly known as the Delphinium of the mountains, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its tall, sparsely branched stems that bear clusters of blue to purple flowers. The leaves are palmately compound, with deeply lobed leaflets that are hairy and grayish-green in appearance. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or alpine environments. The plant's showy flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
